THE POPULAR SONG.
r ANY persons think it an extremely difficult matter to write a popular
song. As a matter of fact, few tasks are more simple. The rub comes
after the song is written, and the real work consists in making a popular song popular. There is only one way under the sun to do this and that is
to let people hear it.
I have received hundreds of letters reading about like this:
"DEAR MR. HAVRZ-I have just completed a song and want you to tell me
how to make it popular. It strikes me as possessing all the catchy features of
the present day 'hits,' and I don't see why it shouldn't be a go, etc., etc."
My invariable reply is, "Get someone on the stage to sing it." This is the
true secret of making a song popular. Just about ninety per cent. of the hits
of today in the song field are the most inane things imaginable, and anybody
Who would prophecy success for any one of them before it was produced would
be voted crazy by a jury of his fellows; but the fact remains that the most
mediocre song in the world, if pumped into the public ear night after night,
will make some kind of a hit.
Nowadays, publishers pay actresses, excuse the word, for singing their
songs. About fifty soubrettes were warbling "Dolly Gray" for' a specified
sum per week. The result was it made a hit. "I must a been Dreamin'" was
another that had to be pushed with money. Yet it scored heavily. Both these
songs were purchased by the publisher in a bunch of fifty or more ditties
acquired by a firm that failed, which were afterwards disposed of for almost
nothing.
"Annie Moore," that nightmare of harmony, lay in a publisher's safe about
five years before he thought fit to put it out. "Hello, my Baby," was hawked
about to many New York ,publishers, all of whom refused it, saying that it was
rot. It was finally sold to one publisher for $5, and when he bought it he
thought he had been buncoed.
A stranger with a bundle of songs stands as much chance in New York
among the publishers as a book agent. He is put off, told to wait, asked to
Come in again, or told the manager is busy and can't see him. I have seen
many a sad sight in the New York publishing houses. Composers with really
good material, anxious to play their work to the publisher, wait in vain for an
opportunity.
On one occasion I was sitting in the private office of a large publisher when
the outer guard, if I may so call him, entered and said that there was a young
man outside with three songs to submit. "Tell him I'm busy or I'm out or in
Chicago, or anything," said the publisher, and turning to me, continued:

My mission being ended, I went into the outer office and saw a picture of woe. The man who had asked for the publisher had a bundle of badly
soiled songs under his arm. and a woe-begone expression on his face. Notwithstanding the fact that there was a heavy snowfall, his shoes were so worn
that his toes protruded. I took him into one of the palatial rooms near by,
and motioned him to the piano. He drew his hands from his trousers pockets
and tried to play, but his fingers were numb with the cold. I sent out for some
brandy for him and under its influence he was soon able to use his fingers. He
then played three excessively pretty songs, which I insisted on the publisher
hearing. The result was that all three songs were accepted; one of them is at
the present time a distinct hit.
How different it is with a man or a woman who has written a successful
song! The moment a successful song writer walks into a publisher's office, he
is almost hugged. His slightest word is eagerly listened to, and every comment
he makes is carefully taken note of. Everything is done to make him comfortable, and be feels a degree of elation that is remarkable. All this because
he has written something in the popular vein, and the publisher wants another
money-maker from him.
It is a senseless method of procedure to publish a song anywhere except in
New York City. That is the home .of the actor and singer. and consequently
the stronghold of the publisher. It is a thousand to one bet that a hit cannot
be made of a song except when it is published in New York
Last, but not least, no publisher will take up a song that is in any degree
complicated or "good." The music must be commonplace and the words even
more so. The publisher says: ''The public want trash; why not give it to

A PLEA FOR SIMPLICITY IN DICTION.
OW often are we imposed upon by the clang of cymbals and the clash of
sounding brass! How often the very makers of this noise deceive themselves! Writers and speakers are often prone to swell their periods with
high-sounding words, merely for the sake of sound. Not only is this to be found
in the speeches of the curbstone orator and of the ranting preacher, but even
in higher intellectual strata. Charlatans are more numerous in literary fields
to-day than they ever were in the time of the original magician. We have dross '
showered upon us. We are stormed at until our ear-drums protest against the
strain.
There are two great reasons for the existence of this empty fiuff ball style
of language. The first is a desire to dress up in tinsel; the second cause, and
probably the most usual, is the lack of cogent, logical thought upon the subject
matter.

It is not surprising that a student who has just made his acquaintance with
a number of "large" words should be anxious to exercise his vocabulary to its
full extent. In a debate in our halls, a "senator" relieved himself of the following sententious bundle of words which had been weighing upon his mind:
Gentlemen, we postulate our position under the orderly march of cumulative
facts." Having howled this out, his face beamed with conscious pride, and his
chest was strained to its utmost capacity.
Nor is the undergraduate the only one who seeks to impress his audience.
A graduate student of several years standing perplexed a seminary meeting by
using the term "altruistic individualism." "Subjective-objectivity" was once
ventured in a lecture room.
Nor again have we reached the limit to which this sin pervades our halls of
learning. I have heard even worthy instructors upon "off days" spin out the
thread of their discourse so thin that it was in imminent danger of being worn
out in the process.
Upon one occasion while taking notes in a lecture, my mind wandered, and
my note taking became merely mechanical. Upon reading the note-book over,
I found one simple proposition stated in six different ways.
Once upon a time a Spaniard, without any knowledge whatever of the Ung•
lish language, attempted to translate with the aid of a bilingual dictionary the
Classics of his tongue into English. The result is most grotesque—a conglomeration of words thrown higglity-pigglity upon the page, full of sound but
meaningless.
This poor Spaniard knew no better, and may be pardoned with a pitying
smile, but for the deliberate villian who stones us with mere "words, words,
words," no fate is too hard.
Sometimes the long-winded, gorgeous-hued language conveys ideas worth
getting, but one is very apt to be so engrossed in examining the wax flowers as
to miss the meaning, disproportionate as it is to the sound and length of the
expressing medium.
A famous lawyer, while addressing a jury, having used all the epithetics
in the dictionary, hesitated a moment, and then added, "this naufrageons ruffian." He was afterwards asked what the word meant, and replied that he did
not know, but "he thought it sounded well."
That is the raison d'etre of so many a speech; sound instead of sense. Now,
In our "hurry up" day, we have not the time to waste upon mere sound.
Those who enjoy it had better take themselves to a "boiler shop." The
Speech abounding in "glittering generalities," which states the proposition
that 2+2-4 in language worthy of Cicero, is aptly described by the slang expression "hot air."
To escape the charge of "hot airing" myself, I will drop my pen before
exhibiting too many examples of the evil I have been abusing.
R. M. D., '02.

N making its bow for the season of 1902-1903, THE NEWS-LETTER would
like to improve the occasion with a few words.
First of all, to the entering classes. THE NEws-LnTTER is the only
student periodical publication of the University. It has to combine, in greater
or less degree, the features of a news weekly, a literary monthly, and a comic
paper. In preparing and stirring up such a mixture, the editors have their
troubles. The recompense they are looking to is your hearty support, not
only with your subscriptions, but in no less degree with contributions of matter suitable for publication.
Next, to our critics. It is true that criticism is a salutary thing; the editors fully realize this, and are duly thankful for having been saved so often.
But we cannot help thinking sometimes: If you are so solicitous about the
reputation of the paper, why don't you help to improve it? The little trouble
needed to jot down and hand in the idea for an article, sketch, or poem, would
very often bring about an attractive feature in the next number. And to those
few,—for there are a few,—who confess to a lack of immediate interest in the
paper, we would say: Did you ever think that the THE NEWS-LETTER iS exchanged to most colleges of note in the United States and Canada, and that
from it many men in these colleges will get their idea of the quantity and
quality of spirit in our undergradnate life? If you have at heart, in the slightest degree, the reputation of the college, you will put some little effort into
helping its official representative abroad.

HE question of the existence of a 1902 foot-ball team is the first that will
occupy the attention of the newly elected Athletic Board. Since 1897,
the University has had a team each season, and it has always been well
supported and creditable. This year, however, the prospect is very doubtful.
There are not more than half a dozen men in the undergraduate department
who are up to the standard of a Hopkins team, and some difficulty has been experienced in making up the number at the medical school. It would seem that
among our entering class of 101, from colleges in every part of the States, a few
enthusiasts could be found. But the change in the schedule of the first-year work
is keeping the class so busy that even the most enthusiastic dread to lose from
their courses the time of steady foot-ball practice. Captain Blanck and those
who have the welfare of the team at heart are, of course, unwilling to have the
University represented by light, inexperienced players, who would prove easy
marks for our opponents. Mr Garwood, the coach for this year, is confident
that he can produce the necessary men from the Medical School if some enthusiasm is shown on this side of town. And so the matter stands. The decision
of the Athletic Board will be announced this afternoon. If it is for the team, it
will then be "up to" every student who has the slightest ability to get on his
foot-ball clothes and attend practice regularly. Every effort will be needed, for
our honor will be at stake.

T one of the gentle controversies with which Freshmen and Juniors have
recently been delighting all beholders, some Seniors present called for a
cessation of hostilities, after matters had proceeded to a gory and dusty
climax. Much to the surprise of all present, a few revolutionary spirits announced that it was their own affair, and that no interference was wanted, so
much so that a little physical suasion had to be applied until the rest of the
combatants filed out. This attitude of the underclassmen is by no means a
new one, but it is none the less thoroughly mistaken. Because the Senior's
participation in such affairs is no longer active, it does not follow that he is a
"has-been," and should show no interest. It is his duty, no less than his inclination, to be on hand at all class troubles, and to be responsible for their
proper conducting. He has been through it all; he has sprawled in defeat, and
crowed in triumph, and no one knows better when there has been enough. At
a Northern college visited by the writer this fall, there was an unwritten law
that no hazing should take place without the presence of an upperclassman.
The principle illustrated is the right one. There should be no repetition of the
spectacle of Seniors exerting force to show their authority.

THE POPULAR SONG.
r ANY persons think it an extremely difficult matter to write a popular
song. As a matter of fact, few tasks are more simple. The rub comes
after the song is written, and the real work consists in making a popular song popular. There is only one way under the sun to do this and that is
to let people hear it.
I have received hundreds of letters reading about like this:
"DEAR MR. HAVRZ-I have just completed a song and want you to tell me
how to make it popular. It strikes me as possessing all the catchy features of
the present day 'hits,' and I don't see why it shouldn't be a go, etc., etc."
My invariable reply is, "Get someone on the stage to sing it." This is the
true secret of making a song popular. Just about ninety per cent. of the hits
of today in the song field are the most inane things imaginable, and anybody
Who would prophecy success for any one of them before it was produced would
be voted crazy by a jury of his fellows; but the fact remains that the most
mediocre song in the world, if pumped into the public ear night after night,
will make some kind of a hit.
Nowadays, publishers pay actresses, excuse the word, for singing their
songs. About fifty soubrettes were warbling "Dolly Gray" for' a specified
sum per week. The result was it made a hit. "I must a been Dreamin'" was
another that had to be pushed with money. Yet it scored heavily. Both these
songs were purchased by the publisher in a bunch of fifty or more ditties
acquired by a firm that failed, which were afterwards disposed of for almost
nothing.
"Annie Moore," that nightmare of harmony, lay in a publisher's safe about
five years before he thought fit to put it out. "Hello, my Baby," was hawked
about to many New York ,publishers, all of whom refused it, saying that it was
rot. It was finally sold to one publisher for $5, and when he bought it he
thought he had been buncoed.
A stranger with a bundle of songs stands as much chance in New York
among the publishers as a book agent. He is put off, told to wait, asked to
Come in again, or told the manager is busy and can't see him. I have seen
many a sad sight in the New York publishing houses. Composers with really
good material, anxious to play their work to the publisher, wait in vain for an
opportunity.
On one occasion I was sitting in the private office of a large publisher when
the outer guard, if I may so call him, entered and said that there was a young
man outside with three songs to submit. "Tell him I'm busy or I'm out or in
Chicago, or anything," said the publisher, and turning to me, continued:

A PLEA FOR SIMPLICITY IN DICTION.
OW often are we imposed upon by the clang of cymbals and the clash of
sounding brass! How often the very makers of this noise deceive themselves! Writers and speakers are often prone to swell their periods with
high-sounding words, merely for the sake of sound. Not only is this to be found
in the speeches of the curbstone orator and of the ranting preacher, but even
in higher intellectual strata. Charlatans are more numerous in literary fields
to-day than they ever were in the time of the original magician. We have dross '
showered upon us. We are stormed at until our ear-drums protest against the
strain.
There are two great reasons for the existence of this empty fiuff ball style
of language. The first is a desire to dress up in tinsel; the second cause, and
probably the most usual, is the lack of cogent, logical thought upon the subject
matter.

It is not surprising that a student who has just made his acquaintance with
a number of "large" words should be anxious to exercise his vocabulary to its
full extent. In a debate in our halls, a "senator" relieved himself of the following sententious bundle of words which had been weighing upon his mind:
Gentlemen, we postulate our position under the orderly march of cumulative
facts." Having howled this out, his face beamed with conscious pride, and his
chest was strained to its utmost capacity.
Nor is the undergraduate the only one who seeks to impress his audience.
A graduate student of several years standing perplexed a seminary meeting by
using the term "altruistic individualism." "Subjective-objectivity" was once
ventured in a lecture room.
Nor again have we reached the limit to which this sin pervades our halls of
learning. I have heard even worthy instructors upon "off days" spin out the
thread of their discourse so thin that it was in imminent danger of being worn
out in the process.
Upon one occasion while taking notes in a lecture, my mind wandered, and
my note taking became merely mechanical. Upon reading the note-book over,
I found one simple proposition stated in six different ways.
Once upon a time a Spaniard, without any knowledge whatever of the Ung•
lish language, attempted to translate with the aid of a bilingual dictionary the
Classics of his tongue into English. The result is most grotesque—a conglomeration of words thrown higglity-pigglity upon the page, full of sound but
meaningless.
This poor Spaniard knew no better, and may be pardoned with a pitying
smile, but for the deliberate villian who stones us with mere "words, words,
words," no fate is too hard.
Sometimes the long-winded, gorgeous-hued language conveys ideas worth
getting, but one is very apt to be so engrossed in examining the wax flowers as
to miss the meaning, disproportionate as it is to the sound and length of the
expressing medium.
A famous lawyer, while addressing a jury, having used all the epithetics
in the dictionary, hesitated a moment, and then added, "this naufrageons ruffian." He was afterwards asked what the word meant, and replied that he did
not know, but "he thought it sounded well."
That is the raison d'etre of so many a speech; sound instead of sense. Now,
In our "hurry up" day, we have not the time to waste upon mere sound.
Those who enjoy it had better take themselves to a "boiler shop." The
Speech abounding in "glittering generalities," which states the proposition
that 2+2-4 in language worthy of Cicero, is aptly described by the slang expression "hot air."
To escape the charge of "hot airing" myself, I will drop my pen before
exhibiting too many examples of the evil I have been abusing.
R. M. D., '02.

T one of the gentle controversies with which Freshmen and Juniors have
recently been delighting all beholders, some Seniors present called for a
cessation of hostilities, after matters had proceeded to a gory and dusty

participation in such affairs is no longer active, it does not follow that he is a
"has-been," and should show no interest. It is his duty, no less than his inclination, to be on hand at all class troubles, and to be responsible for their

crowed in triumph, and no one knows better when there has been enough. At
a Northern college visited by the writer this fall, there was an unwritten law
that no hazing should take place without the presence of an upperclassman.
The principle illustrated is the right one. There should be no repetition of the
spectacle of Seniors exerting force to show their authority.
